message.content: This question requires knowledge about what constitutes pollution. Pollution refers to the introduction of harmful substances or contaminants into the environment, causing negative effects on living organisms. Option (B) is the correct answer because throwing plastic in the ocean is a clear example of pollution. Plastics in the ocean harm marine life and contribute to the degradation of the ecosystem. Options (A), (C), and (D) are not examples of pollution. Recycling old glass to make a house (A) and using old shirts to make a blanket (D) are examples of reusing materials, which is actually a sustainable practice. Donating clothes to a thrift shop (C) is an example of giving used items a second life and reducing waste, which is also a positive action for the environment.

This question requires an understanding of the definition of pollution. Pollution refers to the introduction of harmful substances or contaminants into the environment, which can cause harm to organisms. Option (B) is the correct answer because throwing plastic in the ocean is an example of pollution. Plastic can harm marine life and disrupt ecosystems. Options (A), (C), and (D) are not examples of pollution because they involve reusing or repurposing materials, which is actually a form of recycling or donation.

This question requires knowledge about environmental pollution. Options (A), (C), and (D) do not involve any form of pollution. Option (B), on the other hand, involves throwing plastic in the ocean, which is a form of pollution. Plastics in the ocean can harm marine life, disrupt ecosystems, and degrade water quality, making it the correct answer.

This question requires knowledge about what constitutes pollution. Pollution refers to the presence or introduction of harmful substances or contaminants into the environment that cause adverse effects. Option (B) is the correct answer because throwing plastic in the ocean is an example of pollution as it introduces harmful waste materials into the marine ecosystem. Option (A) is incorrect because recycling old glass to make a house is a form of waste reduction and sustainability, not pollution. Option (C) is incorrect because donating clothes to a thrift shop is an act of reusing and reducing waste, not pollution. Option (D) is incorrect because using old shirts to make a blanket is also an act of reusing and reducing waste, not pollution.

This question requires an understanding of what pollution means. Pollution refers to the contamination of the environment with harmful substances and materials. Among the given options, throwing plastic in the ocean is an example of pollution because it contributes to the accumulation of plastic waste in the ocean, which harms marine life and ecosystems. Option (A) is incorrect because recycling old glass is a form of waste reduction and conservation. Option (C) is incorrect because donating clothes to a thrift shop promotes reuse and reduces waste. Option (D) is incorrect because using old shirts to make a blanket is also a form of reuse and waste reduction.

This question requires knowledge about different types of pollution. Option (B) is correct because throwing plastic in the ocean is an example of water pollution, which is harmful to marine life and ecosystems. Option (A) is incorrect because recycling is a positive action that helps reduce pollution. Option (C) is incorrect because donating clothes to a thrift shop is a form of recycling and reduces waste. Option (D) is incorrect because using old shirts to make a blanket is a form of upcycling and also reduces waste.

This question requires understanding of what constitutes pollution. Pollution refers to the introduction of harmful substances or contaminants into the environment, which can have negative effects on the ecosystem and human health. Option (B) is the correct answer because throwing plastic in the ocean is an example of pollution, as it can harm marine life and contribute to the problem of plastic pollution in the oceans. 

Options (A), (C), and (D) are examples of recycling or reusing materials, which are actually beneficial for the environment and not considered as pollution. Recycling old glass to make a house (option A) and using old shirts to make a blanket (option D) are both examples of repurposing and reducing waste. Donating clothes to a thrift shop (option C) is a form of reusing and extending the life cycle of clothing items. These actions contribute to waste reduction and sustainability.

Option (B) is the correct answer because throwing plastic in the ocean is a form of pollution that can harm marine life and disrupt ecosystems. Options (A), (C), and (D) are all examples of recycling or reusing materials, which is actually a positive environmental practice and not considered pollution.
